posts._title: Howard Hughes – Stagecoach to Tombstone: The Filmgoer’s Guide to Great Westerns (2008)
posts.title: Stagecoach to Tombstone: The Filmgoer’s Guide to Great Westerns
posts.excerpt: British author Howard Hughes charts the development of the modern Western movie in this insightful, informative volume published in 2008 by Tauris & Company. By examining 27 movies he views as key, Hughes shows the evolving nature of the genre. Western fans are in for an interesting ride since the films range from classics like …

posts._title: Douglas Brode – Fantastic Planets, Forbidden Zones and Lost Continents (2015)
posts.title: Fantastic Planets, Forbidden Zones and Lost Continents
posts.excerpt: Whether you judge by box office receipts, industry awards, or critical accolades, science fiction films are the most popular movies now being produced and distributed around the world. Nor is this phenomenon new. Sci-fi filmmakers and audiences have been exploring fantastic planets, forbidden zones, and lost continents ever since George Méliès’ 1902 film A Trip …

posts._title: Marijke de Valck – Cinephilia: Movies, Love and Memory (Film Culture in Transition) (2005)
posts.title: Cinephilia: Movies, Love and Memory (Film Culture in Transition)
posts.excerpt: Quote: Publisher description for Cinephilia : movies, love and memory / edited by Marijke de Valck and Malte Hagener. They obsess over the nuances of a Douglas Sirk or Ingmar Bergman film; they revel in books such as François Truffaut’s Hitchcock; they happily subscribe to the Sundance Channel—they are the rare breed known as cinephiles. …

posts._title: Vitali Kanevsky – Zamri, umri, voskresni! AKA Freeze Die Come to Life (1990)
posts.title: Zamri, umri, voskresni!
posts.excerpt: Quote: “Freeze-Die-Come to Life,” a first film by Vitaly Kanevski, offers a stark look at growing up in the frozen wastes of the Soviet Union at the end of World War II. A largely autobiographical work, it is the sweetly grim story of a couple of street-smart kids in the mining town of Suchan. A …

posts.title: Tirza
posts.excerpt: Quote: Jörgen Hofmeester is desperately looking for his missing daughter Tirza and heading towards a brutal confrontation with the man who has been the undoing of his favorite child.

posts.title: Il mare
posts.excerpt: Quote: Tourist season has not yet begun. Capri is deserted and the sky is sadly grey. An actor arrives. He’s waiting for a woman who won’t come. In the meanwhile he’s having a strange relationship with a young alcoholic man who even tries to kill him; he’s bored, with no ideals, strong and weak at …

posts._title: Gustav Deutsch – Shirley: Visions of Reality (2013)
posts.title: Shirley: Visions of Reality
posts.excerpt: Quote: Seldom has the idea of a film as a series of tableaux been so literally appropriate as in the latest work from Austrian filmmaker and artist Gustav Deutsch. Shirley – Visions of Reality is a look at the US from the 1930s to the 1960s as seen through a series of micro-stories set in …

posts._title: Peter Brook – Moderato cantabile AKA Seven Days… Seven Nights (1960)
posts.title: Moderato cantabile
posts.excerpt: Synopsis: A wealthy and bored woman is witness of a murder in affection and meets another witness. She asks him about the history of the victim and falls in love with him. — IMDb. Review: One of those movies that mesmerizes through its restraint, this is set in a dreary coastal small town—familiar territory for …

posts._title: Omar Amiralay – A Flood in Baath Country aka Al Toufan (2005)
posts.title: A Flood in Baath Country
posts.excerpt: A highly controversial and beautifully crafted film on Syria’s dictatorship. Omar Amiralay’s film about the dictatorship in Syria highlights the devastating effects of 35 years of autocratic Baath party rule on society. Thirty-four years ago, Amiralay was an admirer of the modernisation of his country and even made his first short essay-like documentary in praise …

posts._title: Carlos Saura – Cría cuervos AKA Raise Ravens (1976)
posts.title: Cría cuervos
posts.excerpt: Quote: An inquisitive, cherubic girl named Ana (Ana Torrent) overhears a tender exchange between her father, a military officer named Anselmo (Héctor Alterio) and his mistress, Amelia (Mirta Miller), before the intimate moment gives way to tragedy and confusion, as Anselmo suffers a fatal heart attack. Amelia hurriedly dresses, leaving Anselmo’s body alone in the …
